Knowledge Point: The stress-bearing (§\ref{sec:stress.prefixal.chain}) \forme{mɯ́j-} prefix (see \ref{ex:WmAtaZa} below) is a portmanteau of negation and Sensory evidental (§\ref{sec:sensory}). The Sensory prefix \forme{ɲɯ-} has the expected negative form \forme{mɯ-ɲɯ-} only in the case of contracting verbs (§\ref{sec:sensory.morphology}). Otherwise, when the prefixal sequence \forme{mɯ-ɲɯ-} occurs, the \forme{ɲɯ-} preverb marks the Imperfective (§\ref{sec:ipfv.morphology}).
Content 1: \gll tɕe tɯ-ŋke ɯ-mɤ-ta-ʑa, ɯ-mɤ-nɯ-mɯnmu qʰe mɯ́j-sɤ-mto | \gls LNK INF:II-walk QU-NEG-AOR:3\flobv{}-start QU-NEG-AOR-move LNK NEG:SENS-PROP-see | \glt `If it has not started walking, if it has not moved, it is not visible.'

Knowledge Point: The form \forme{mɤ-} is found on non-finite verbal forms without any orientation preverb (§\ref{sec:subject.participle.other.prefixes}, §\ref{sec:object.participle.other.prefixes}, §\ref{sec:infinitives.other.prefixes}, §\ref{sec:degree.nominal.prefixes}), in Factual Non-Past and Irrealis form (see \ref{ex:amAGWtAtWwGndza} above in §\ref{sec:outer.prefixal.chain}), and also when preceded by the interrogative \forme{ɯ-} (§\ref{sec:interrogative.W.morpho}) as in (\ref{ex:WmAtaZa}) and the Proximative \forme{jɯ-} (§\ref{sec:proximative}) as in (\ref{ex:jWmACtAthuta}).
Content 1: \gll qapar kɯ nɤʑo a^{-6}-mɤ^{-5}-ɣɯ^{-4}-tɤ^{-3}-tɯ́^{-2}-wɣ^{-1}-ndza | \gls dhole ERG 2SG IRR^{-6}-NEG^{-5}-CISL^{-4}-PFV^{-3}-2^{-2}-INV^{-1}-eat | \glt `(Let us hope that) the dhole will not come to eat you.'
Content 2: \gll tɕe tɯ-ŋke ɯ-mɤ-ta-ʑa, ɯ-mɤ-nɯ-mɯnmu qʰe mɯ́j-sɤ-mto | \gls LNK INF:II-walk QU-NEG-AOR:3\flobv{}-start QU-NEG-AOR-move LNK NEG:SENS-PROP-see | \glt `If it has not started walking, if it has not moved, it is not visible.'
Content 3: \gll jɯfɕɯr jɯ-mɤ-ɕ-tɤ-tʰu-t-a ʑo | \gls yesterday PROXM-NEG-TRAL-AOR-ask-PST:TR-1SG EMPH | \glt `Yesterday I almost did not go and ask about it.'

Knowledge Point: The partial reduplication (§\ref{sec:verb.initial.redp}) of \forme{mɯ-} (which occurs in particular in the protasis of conditionals, §\ref{sec:redp.protasis}) does not yield expected \dagger\forme{mɯ\redp{}mɯ\trt}, but rather \forme{mɯ\redp{}mɤ-} with vowel alternation: compare for instance \forme{mɯ-nɯ-si} `she did not die' with the \forme{mɯ-} prefix (as expected in the Aorist) with \forme{mɯ\redp{}mɤ-nɯ-si-a} `if I do not die' in (\ref{ex:mWmAnWsia}).
Content 1: \gll mɯ\redp{}mɤ-nɯ-si-a nɤ, a-tɤ-kɯ-nɯlaʁrdaβ-a ra | \gls COND\redp{}NEG-AOR-die-1SG ADD IRR-PFV-2\fl{}1-hit.with.forelegs-1SG be.needed:FACT | \glt `If [after that] I have not died [yet], hit me with your forelegs.'

Knowledge Point: The Interrogative \forme{ɯ-} prefix, like conditional reduplication, requires the \forme{mɤ-} negative prefix (see \ref{ex:WmAtaZa} above), and this commonality in morphophonology is correlated with a similarity in function, since both the prefix \forme{ɯ-} and reduplication are used to mark the verb of the protasis of conditional clauses (§\ref{sec:real.conditional}).
Content 1: \gll tɕe tɯ-ŋke ɯ-mɤ-ta-ʑa, ɯ-mɤ-nɯ-mɯnmu qʰe mɯ́j-sɤ-mto | \gls LNK INF:II-walk QU-NEG-AOR:3\flobv{}-start QU-NEG-AOR-move LNK NEG:SENS-PROP-see | \glt `If it has not started walking, if it has not moved, it is not visible.'

Knowledge Point: The -6 slot \forme{ɯmɤ-} prefix of possible modality (§\ref{sec:WmA}) has a surface form identical to the combination of the interrogative \forme{ɯ-} with the negative prefix \forme{mɤ\trt}, as in (\ref{ex:tundze.WmANu}). The \forme{ɯmɤ-} synchronically differs from \forme{ɯ-mɤ-} (from which it historically derives) in that it can occur with the peg circumfix (§\ref{sec:peg.circumfix}, §\ref{sec:WmA.kW.ci}). It is not compatible with a negative prefix.
Content 1: \gll qajɯ kɯ-fse ra tu-ndze ɯmɤ-ŋu ma | \gls bug SBJ:PCP-be.like PL IPFV-eat[III] PROB-be:FACT LNK | \glt `It presumably/maybe eats bugs.'

Knowledge Point: For instance, the negation of \japhug{ŋu}{be} and \japhug{tu}{exist} can only be \japhug{maʁ}{not be} (\ref{ex:aZo.maRa}) and \japhug{me}{not exist} (\ref{ex:tWtshot.pWme}).
Content 1: \gll aʑo maʁ-a | \gls 1SG not.be:FACT-1SG | \glt `I am not [that girl].'
Content 2: \gll kɯɕɯŋgɯ tɕe tɯtsʰot pɯ-me tɕe, | \gls former.times LOC clocks PST.IPFV-not.exist LNK | \glt `In former times, there were no clocks.'

Knowledge Point: It is however possible to combine affirmative copulas or existential verbs with their negative counterparts as postverbal periphrastic negations (§\ref{sec:periphrastic.negation}). The copulas \forme{ŋu} and \forme{maʁ} occur together in the phrase \forme{ŋu cinɤ maʁ kɯ} `in any case it is not true' (example \ref{ex:Nu.cinA.maR.kW}, §\ref{sec:cinA}). The negative existential \japhug{me}{not exist} is very commonly found with the participle of its antonym \forme{kɯ-tu} to express emphasis on the non-existence, as in (\ref{ex:pWkWtu.me}) in comparison with (\ref{ex:tWtshot.pWme}) (§\ref{sec:existential.basic}).
Content 1: \gll qajdo kɯ tɕʰi mɤ-nɯ-ti ɕti nɤ, a-tɤ-nɯ-ti ma ŋu cinɤ maʁ kɯ, nɯ sɤznɤ kɯ-scɯ-scit rɤʑi-tɕi | \gls crow ERG what NEG-AUTO-say:FACT be.AFF:FACT LNK IRR-PFV-AUTO-say LNK be:FACT even not.be:FACT SFP DEM COMP SBJ:PCP-EMPH\redp{}happy stay:FACT-1DU | \glt `What wouldn't a crow say (a crow tells only lies), let it say what it wants, in any case none of it is true, let us live [together] happily rather (than worrying about that).'
Content 2: \gll kɯɕɯŋgɯ mkʰɯrlu kɯ-fse ra pɯ-kɯ-tu me. | \gls former.times machine SBJ:PCP-be.like PL PST.IPFV-SBJ:PCP-exist not.exist:FACT | \glt `In former times, there were no machines or things like that at all.'
Content 3: \gll kɯɕɯŋgɯ tɕe tɯtsʰot pɯ-me tɕe, | \gls former.times LOC clocks PST.IPFV-not.exist LNK | \glt `In former times, there were no clocks.'

Knowledge Point: The verb \japhug{\textsc{neg}+ʑɯ}{not just be}, `not be/have only' (\ref{ex:mAZW.ma}) is most commonly used in one of the comparative constructions (§\ref{sec:mAZW}) and has even been further grammaticalized as an adverb \japhug{mɤʑɯ}{even more} (\ref{ex:mAZW.Zo.chWtshu}).
Content 1: \gll kʰɤjmu nɯtɕu mɤ-ʑɯ ma, tɤrɲɟo tu tɕe, | \gls kitchen DEM:LOC NEG-be.just LNK shelf exist:FACT LNK | \glt `In the kitchen, there are not just [the aforementioned objects], there is also a shelf (to store the cooking implements).'
Content 2: \gll nɯnɯ paʁ kɯ tu-ndze tɕe, mɤʑɯ ʑo cʰɯ-tsʰu cʰa | \gls DEM pig ERG IPFV-eat[III] LNK even.more EMPH IPFV-be.fat can:FACT | \glt `When the pig eats it [acorns], it can grow even fatter.'

Knowledge Point: Second, most \forme{sɯ-/z-} abilitative verbs (§\ref{sec:abilitative}) are only found in negative forms. For instance the abilitative \forme{z-nɤjo} from \japhug{nɤjo}{wait} only occurs with a negation in the meaning `cannot wait to' (due to hurry/impatience) as in (\ref{ex:juzGWt.mWpjAznAjo}).
Content 1: \gll spjaŋkɯ nɯ kɯ ju-zɣɯt mɯ-pjɤ-z-nɤjo ʑo tɕe, | \gls wolf DEM ERG IPFV-arrive NEG-IFR.IPFV-ABIL-wait EMPH LNK | \glt `The wolf could not wait [for the fox] to arrive.'

Knowledge Point: This constraint is also observed with the lexicalized abilitative \japhug{spʰɯt}{can cut} (from \japhug{pʰɯt}{take out, cut}, §\ref {sec:abilitative.lexicalized}) as in (\ref{ex:WndzrW.mWjsphWt}).
Content 1: \gll tsɯntu kɯ ɯ-ndzrɯ mɯ́j-spʰɯt ma ɯ-tɯ-rko ɯ-tɯ-jaʁ ɲɯ-sɤre ʑo | \gls scissors ERG 3SG.POSS-nail NEG:SENS-can.cut LNK 3SG.POSS-NMLZ:DEG-be.hard 3SG.POSS-NMLZ:DEG-be.thick SENS-be.ridiculous EMPH | \glt `The scissors cannot cut through her nails, as they are extremely hard and thick.'

Knowledge Point: First, the negative form of the underived form of the root can have an extended meaning. For instance, the verb \japhug{rkaŋ}{be strong}, `be in good physical condition' can mean `be pregnant' in the negative as in (\ref{ex:mWYArkaN}).
Content 1: \gll ki tɕʰeme ki mɯ-ɲɤ-rkaŋ | \gls DEM.PROX girl DEM.PROX NEG-IFR-be.in.good.shape | \glt `This woman became pregnant.'

Knowledge Point: Third, some lexicalized noun-verb collocations require a negative prefix on the verb (§\ref{sec:other.collocation.intr}), for instance \forme{tɯ-skʰrɯ=\textsc{neg}-βdi} `be pregnant' from \japhug{tɯ-skʰrɯ}{body} and \japhug{βdi}{be well} as in (\ref{ex:ndZiskhrW.mWYABdi}).
Content 1: \gll ndʑi-rʑaβ ʁnaʁna ʑo ndʑi-skʰrɯ mɯ-ɲɤ-βdi | \gls 3DU.POSS-wife both EMPH 3DU.POSS-body NEG-IFR-be.well | \glt `Both of their wives got pregnant.'

Knowledge Point: Aside from negative prefixes (\ref{ex:mWpWmtota}), negation can be expressed by the negative copula \japhug{maʁ}{not be} (\ref{ex:pWmtota.maR}) and the negative existential verb \japhug{me}{not exist} (\ref{ex:pWmtota.me}) in postverbal position.
Content 1: \gll mɯ-pɯ-mto-t-a | \gls NEG-AOR-see-PST:TR-1SG | \glt `I have not seen it.'
Content 2: \gll pɯ-mto-t-a maʁ | \gls AOR-see-PST:TR-1SG not.be:FACT | \glt `I have not seen it, (but rather...).' | '
Content 3: \gll pɯ-mto-t-a me | \gls AOR-see-PST:TR-1SG not.exist:FACT | \glt `I have seen none/I haven't seen anything.'

Knowledge Point: The negative copula \japhug{maʁ}{not be} occurs postverbally in Periphrastic TAME categories requiring a copula (§\ref{sec:ipfv.periphrastic.TAME}), or to express emphatic negation, contrasting with an assertative postverbal copula (§\ref{sec:affirmative.copula.function}) as in (\ref{ex:YWGAwua.maR}).
Content 1: \gll ɲɯ-ɣɤwu-a maʁ nɤ, tɯ-mɯ pjɯ-lɤt ɲɯ-ɕti ma | \gls SENS-cry-1SG not.be:FACT SFP INDEF.POSS-sky IPFV-release SENS-be.AFF LNK | \glt `It is not that I am crying, [I look like I am crying because] it has been raining.'

Knowledge Point: The postverbal negative existential \forme{me} (§\ref{sec:existential.basic}) has a universal negative meaning `nothing' or negative indefinite `none, not any' as in (\ref{ex:pWmtota.me}) (§\ref{sec:negation.existential}).
Content 1: \gll pɯ-mto-t-a me | \gls AOR-see-PST:TR-1SG not.exist:FACT | \glt `I have seen none/I haven't seen anything.'

Knowledge Point: It is also found in one of the superlative constructions, illustrated by example (\ref{ex:tuqhea.me}) (§\ref{sec:negative.existential.superlative}).
Content 1: \gll βʑɯ kɯ-fse tu-qʰe-a me | \gls mouse SBJ:PCP-be.like IPFV-hate[III]-1SG not.exist:FACT | \glt `Mice is what I hate most.'

Knowledge Point: Double negation with existential verbs can indicate universal quantification, in particular when the verb taking the negative prefix is transitive (or semi-transitive) and no overt object (or semi-object) is present as in (\ref{ex:mAndze.Zo.me}) (see also §\ref{sec:negation.existential}).
Content 1: \gll paʁ aɣɯɣli ma rcanɯ mɤ-ndze ʑo me | \gls pig produce.a.lot.of.manure:FACT LNK UNEXP:DEG NEG-eat[III] EMPH not.exist:FACT | \glt `Pigs produce a lot of manure, as they eat everything (there is nothing they don't eat).'

Knowledge Point: Negative participial forms with a negative auxiliary express mild assertion, as in (\ref{ex:mAkWpe.me}) and (\ref{ex:mAkWkhW.me}).
Content 1: \gll aʑɯɣ mɤ-kɯ-pe me | \gls 1SG:GEN NEG-SBJ:PCP-be.good not.exist:FACT | \glt `I am fine (I don't have any particular problem).'
Content 2: \gll mɤ-kɯ-kʰɯ me | \gls NEG-SBJ:PCP-be.possible not.exist:FACT | \glt `There is nothing wrong with it.'

Knowledge Point: Another type of double negation construction is observed when both the com\-plement-taking verb and the verb in the complement clause take a negative prefix. The most common verb in this type of configuration is the modal verb \japhug{kʰɯ}{be possible} (§\ref{sec:ra.khW.jAG.verb}), either with finite complements (§\ref{sec:finite.complement}) as in (\ref{ex:mAGia.mAkhW}), or with negative infinitival complements (example \ref{ex:mAkACe.mAkhW}, §\ref{sec:infinitives.other.prefixes}), expressing the meaning `have no choice but to X'.
Content 1: \gll nɤ-rca mɤ-ɣi-a mɤ-kʰɯ qʰe | \gls 2SG.POSS-together.with NEG-come:FACT-1SG NEG-be.possible:FACT LNK | \glt `It have no other choice but to go with you/follow you.'
Content 2: \gll rɟɤlpu fka ɕti tɕe, mɤ-kɤ-ɕe mɤ-kʰɯ | \gls king order be.AFF:FACT LNK NEG-INF-go NEG-be.possible:FACT | \glt `This is the king's order, [I] have no choice but to go.'

Knowledge Point: Other verbs attested in this type of construction include \japhug{nɤz}{dare} (§\ref{sec:nAz.verb}) as in (\ref{ex:mAkAGi.mAnAzi}) and \japhug{cʰa}{can} (with the meaning `cannot help but' as in \ref{ex:mACWkAtshi}, §\ref{sec:am.complement}).
Content 1: \gll rɟɤlpu fka ɕti tɕe, mɤ-kɤ-ɣi mɤ-nɤz-i ri | \gls king order be.AFF:FACT LNK NEG-INF-come NEG-dare:FACT-1PL LNK | \glt `It is the king's order, we do not dare not to come.'
Content 2: \gll tɯ-nɯ ɯ-kɯ-tsʰi ɲɯ-ɕti-a tɕe, jɤ-azɣɯt-a tɕe, tɯ-nɯ ci mɤ-ɕɯ-kɤ-tsʰi nɯ mɯ́j-cʰa-a | \gls INDEF.POSS-breast 3SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-drink SENS-be.AFF-1SG LNK AOR-arrive-1SG LNK INDEF.POSS-breast INDEF NEG-TRAL-INF-drink DEM NEG:SENS-can-1SG | \glt `I am [a toddler] who [still] drinks [his mother's] milk, when I arrived, I could not help but go and drink milk.'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: Although there is a privative nominal derivation in Japhug (§\ref{sec:privative}), there is no way of building a negative noun like English `non-X' or `un-X' meaning `which is not X' (rather than X-less). The only way to express such a meaning is build using a participial relative (§\ref{sec:subject.participles}) with the negative copula \forme{X kɯ-maʁ} `something/someone who/that is not X' (§\ref{sec:copula.basic}), for instance \forme{tɤ-rɟit kɯ-maʁ} `someone who is not a child' in (\ref{ex:tArJit.kWmaR}).
Content 1: \gll ɯʑora nɯ-rɟit ʑo cʰɯ-βri-nɯ qʰe kɯmaʁ ra nɯ-rɟit nɯ pɯpɯŋunɤ [tɤ-rɟit kɯ-maʁ] tú-wɣ-sɯpa qʰe | \gls 3PL 3PL.POSS-offspring EMPH IPFV-protect-PL LNK other PL 3PL.POSS-offspring DEM TOP INDEF.POSS-child SBJ:PCP-not.be IMPF-INV-consider LNK | \glt `(At school), [some parents] protect their own children, and as for the children of other people, they consider them as if they were not children (`as non-children').'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: Japhug lacks negative pronouns (§\ref{sec:indef.pro}), and headless relative clauses (§\ref{sec:headless.relatives.quantification}) combined with a negative existential copula (§\ref{sec:suppletive.negative}) are used to express the meanings `nothing', `nobody' (\ref{ex:nAkWCaB.me}, \ref{ex:WkWntChoz.maNe}) or `nowhere' (\ref{ex:WsArNgW.maNe}).
Content 1: \gll nɤ-kɯ-ɕaβ me | \gls 2SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-catch.up not.exist:FACT | \glt `Nobody will [be able] to catchup with you.'
Content 2: \gll jinde tɕe nɯ [ɯ-kɯ-ntɕʰoz] maŋe qʰe, [kɤ-mto] kɯnɤ maŋe | \gls nowadays LNK DEM 3SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-use not.exist:SENS LNK OBJ:PCP-see also not.exist:SENS | \glt `Nowadays \textbf{nobody} uses [amadou], there isn't even \textbf{any} to be seen.'
Content 3: \gll tɯmɯrkʰa tɕe ɯ-sɤ-rŋgɯ maŋe | \gls evening LOC 3SG.POSS-OBL:PCP-lie.down not.exist:SENS | \glt `In the evening, it has no place to stay.'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: In negative existential constructions, the headless relative can also mean `not any of' as \forme{kɤ-mto} `any (amadou) to be seen' in (\ref{ex:WkWntChoz.maNe}).
Content 1: \gll jinde tɕe nɯ [ɯ-kɯ-ntɕʰoz] maŋe qʰe, [kɤ-mto] kɯnɤ maŋe | \gls nowadays LNK DEM 3SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-use not.exist:SENS LNK OBJ:PCP-see also not.exist:SENS | \glt `Nowadays \textbf{nobody} uses [amadou], there isn't even \textbf{any} to be seen.'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: The adverb \forme{maka} is generally used with negative verb forms to express emphatic negation `not ... at all' as in (\ref{ex:maka.mWpWjAG}), in particular with negative existential verbs (§\ref{sec:negation.existential}).
Content 1: \gll tɕʰeme kʰɤɕkʰɤr ku-kɯ-ɕe maka mɯ-pɯ-jɤɣ | \gls girl man.seating.place IPFV:EAST-GENR:S/O-go at.all NEG-PST.IPFV-be.allowed | \glt `Ladies were not allowed to go to the men's seating place.'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: It is however attested in non-negative sentences as in (\ref{ex:maka.nWnACqe}), in adversative contexts.
Content 1: \gll jɤxtsʰi ndɤre maka nɯ-nɤɕqe ra | \gls this.time ADVERS at.all IMP-endure[III] be.needed:FACT | \glt `This time (unlike the previous times), you have absolutely to bear [the cold of the moon and the heat of the sun without making a word, otherwise we will not succeed].'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: Rather, it is from the intensifier \forme{mu},\footnote{This form is related to the denominal verb \japhug{mɤmu}{be the most important}. } also attested as intensifier `not... at all' in negative contexts (\ref{ex:muZo.me}), in bound state form \forme{mɤ-} (§\ref{sec:vowel.alternations.compounds}), followed by vowel assimilation with the following syllable \forme{-ka}.
Content 1: \gll nɯ ma kɯ-ra mu ʑo me | \gls DEM apart.from SBJ:PCP-be.needed at.all EMPH not.exist:FACT | \glt `I don't need anything else at all.'

Section: Negation and parts of speech other than verbs
Knowledge Point: We find in addition the compound form \forme{mucin} `not even one at all' (\ref{ex:mucin.Zo.marCAttCi}) from \forme{mu} and \japhug{cinɤ}{(not) even one} (§\ref{sec:cinA}).
Content 1: \gll kɯmdza ra mucin ʑo mɤ-arɕɤt-tɕi | \gls relative PL at.all EMPH NEG-have.a.kinship.relationship:FACT-1DU | \glt `We don't have any kinship relationship at all.'
